Behavioral Factors

Download a PDF of all Behavioral Factors Outcome studies (link TBD)

Assessing a thematic condom advertising campaign on condom use in urban Pakistan

Agha S, Beaudoin CE
Journal of Health Communication, 2012, 17(5): 601-23
Location Pakistan
Population  Men married to women age 15-49 years
Intervention Description  Condom Social Marketing
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Belief, discussion, embarrassment

Behaviors: Condom use, FP use
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 8: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Theory, Competition. Exchange, Segmentation, Methods mix

Rates of IUCD discontinuation and its associated factors among the clients of a social franchising network in Pakistan

Asmat SK, Shaikh BT, Hameed W, Bilgrami M, Mustafa G, Ali M, Ishaque M, Hussain W, Ahmed A
BMC Women's Health, 2012, 12(8): 1-8
Location Pakistan
Population Female clients of Suraj Centers that had received an IUCD
Intervention Description Social Franchise
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Knowledge about IUCD, Accessiblity and use of IUCD,

Behaviors: Provider quality of care, client satisfaction, and discontinuation rates
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability: Multi-stage random sampling
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 4: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Exchange

Changes in the proportion of facility-based deliveries and related maternal health services among the poor in rural Jhang, Pakistan: results from a demand-side financing intervention

Agha S
International Journal for Equity in Health, 2011, 10(57): 1-12
Location Pakistan
Population Pregnant women in the two poorest quintiles in Jhang districtr
Intervention Description Social marketing of voucher booklets valued at Rs.4,000 ($48), including three ANC visits, a PNC visit, an institutional delivery, and a postnatal family planning visit, were sold for Rs. 100 ($1.2) to low-income women targeted by project outreach workers.
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Perceptions of institutional delivery and family planning

Behaviors: Changes in ANC, institutional delivery, PNC, and family planning use
Design Pre-test/post-test Quasi-experimental
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 5
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 6: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Exchange, Segmentation, Methods mix

Comparing private sector family planning services to government and NGO services in Ethiopia and Pakistan: how do social franchises compare across quality, equity and cost?

Shah NM, Wang W, Bishai DM
Health Policy and Planning, 2011, 26(1): i63-i71
Location Pakistan; Ethiopia
Population Providers and clients of franchised clinics
Intervention Description Social Franchise
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Cost of care; Access to poor

Behaviors: Quality of Care: These were provider training in abortion, choice of methods, information given to the clients, client satisfaction, range of services provided and, technical competence of providers;

Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability: Multi-stage cluster sampling
Strength of Evidence Score 3
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 4: Customer orientation, Insight , Exchange, Competition

Using and Joining a Franchised Private Sector Provider Network in Myanmar

O'Connell K, Hom M, Aung T, Theuss M, Huntington D
PLoS ONE, 2011, 6(12): e28364
Location Myanmar
Population Married female clients age 15-49 receiving RH care from franchised clinics; female sex workers receiving STI care from franchised clinics; male and female franchised clinic providers.
Intervention Description Social Franchise
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Client motivation (attitudes, and quality perception) to use and provider motivations (incentives) to join franchised clinics
Design Observational
Sampling Method Snowball and purposive sampling
Strength of Evidence Score 1
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 4: Customer orientation, Insight, Exchange, Competition

Case Study: Does training of private networks of Family Planning clinicians in urban Pakistan affect service utilization?

Qureshi AM
BMC International Health and Human Rights, 2010, 10(26): 1-12
Location Pakistan
Population Clinical and non-clinical providers
Intervention Description Social Franchise
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Training

Behaviors: Quality of care and service use
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability: Stratified random sampling with differential probability of selection
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 2: Behavior, Competition

Impact of an Advertising Campaign on Condom Use in Urban Pakistan

S Agha, Meekers D
Studies in Family Planning, 2010, 41(4): 277-290
Location Pakistan
Population  Men married to women age 15-49 years
Intervention Description  Condom Social Marketing
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Perceived availability, attitudes, discussion

Behaviors: Condom use
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 8: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Theory, Competition, Exchange, Segmentation, Methods mix

A social marketing approach to quality improvement in family planning services: a case study from Rawalpindi, Pakistan

Gulzar J, Ali M, Kuroiwa C
BioScience Trends, 2008, 2(1):15-21
Location Pakistan
Population  Male and Female clients of targeted providers
Intervention Description  Provider targeted social marketing of family planning services
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Product availability, perceived availability,

Behaviors: Quality of care, provider technical competence
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 2
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 3: Behavior, Custormer orientation, Insight

Reaching youth through franchise clinics: assessment of Kenyan private sector involvement in youth services.

Decker M, Montagu D
Journal of Adolescent Health, 2007, 40(3): 280-2
Location Kenya
Population Clients and providers of KMET (social franchise) member clinics and clients and providers of non-member clinics
Intervention Description Social Franchise
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Consumer perceptions of family planning

Behaviors: Consumer-focused outcomes, included use of family planning; Provider-focused outcomes included increased services targeting youth and family planning methods
Design Quasi-experimental
Sampling Method Probabilty
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 2: Behavior, Segmentation

Involving husbands in safe motherhood: effects of the SUAMI SIAGA campaign in Indonesia

Shefner-Rogers CL, Sood S
Journal of Health Communication, 2004, 9(3): 233-58
Location Indonesia
Population Primary audience: Men of reproductive age; Secondary audience: married women of reproductive age, community leaders and groups, midwives
Intervention Description Mass Media Campaign: PSA Television and Radio Broadcast; Print Material
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Exposure to campaign, Changes in knowledge and information-seeking and information-sharing behaviors

Behaviors: Percent of men reporting helping a women who was experiencing pregnancy complications
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability: Multi-stage random sampling
Strength of Evidence Score 2
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 6: Behavior, Theory Customer orientation, Insight, Segmentation, Methods mix
